metadata.case_name: Ram Bali Rajbhar v. Commissioner of Police, Calcutta & Ors.

facts.text: On 5-9-1973 at about 17-40 hrs., petitioner along with associates armed with iron rods, lathis and bombs created disturbance by hurling bombs at tea-stall of Lal Mohan Jadav at 19, Coal Berth, Calcutta, as he refused to supply tea without payment, endangering lives, causing panic, closure of shops, suspension of traffic.

On 7-9-1973 at about 20.05 hrs., petitioner along with associates armed with iron-rods, lathis and bombs attacked watch repairing shop of Sk. Azim at 52, Circular Garden Reach Road, Calcutta, by hurling bombs and damaging property as owner refused to pay for drinks; hurled bombs at interveners.
Detention order issued by Commissioner of Police, Calcutta on 1-10-1973; grounds served same day.
Petitioner discharged by Criminal Court on 1-10-1973.
First representation received by State Government on 18-10-1973.
Detention order approved by State Government on 22-10-1973.
Case sent to Advisory Board on 23-10-1973 with grounds, representation, and report under Sec. 3(3).
Advisory Board gave opinion of sufficient cause on 5-11-1973.
Detention confirmed by State Government on 8-11-1973, served on petitioner on 14-11-1973.
Lal Mohan Jadav swore affidavit on 20-11-1973 stating petitioner did not participate in attack on his shop on 5-9-1973.
Second representation made by petitioner on 27-11-1973, received by State Government on 28-11-1973, still under consideration.
Calcutta High Court rejected Habeas Corpus petition on 21-3-1974.
Kamal Singh Tiger, with identical grounds, released by Advisory Board after personal hearing, finding no sufficient cause.
Petitioner holds licence for money lending and has address in Calcutta, described as homeless in grounds.
Criminal prosecution launched against petitioner on 6-9-1973 for 5-9-1973 incident.

legal_issues.text: Whether grounds of detention are vague, false, mala fide, and lack rational nexus with maintenance of public order.
Whether criminal offences can form basis for preventive detention under MISA, or public order requires threat akin to security of State.
Effect of discharge, affidavit by Lal Mohan Jadav, and comparison with Kamal Singh case on validity of detention.
Whether detaining authorities and Advisory Board applied their minds properly.
Action to be taken on second representation under Section 14 of MISA read with Section 21 of General Clauses Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Grounds of detention are vague, false, mala fide, fanciful, non-existent; no rational nexus with permissible objects of preventive detention.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Maintenance of Internal Security Act; public order wider than law and order

petitioner_arguments.text: Criminal offences meant for prosecution under ordinary law, not preventive detention; public order must be read with security of State.
Detaining authorities did not apply minds: petitioner not homeless, falsely implicated; affidavit by victim exonerates.
Kamal Singh with identical grounds released by Advisory Board.

respondent_arguments.text: Grounds based on criminal activities jeopardising public order; instances of criminal activity can form basis for detention.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Haradhan Saha v. State of West Bengal; Golam Hussain v. Commissioner of Police

respondent_arguments.text: Affidavit by Lal Mohan Jadav procured after discharge, dishonest; Commissioner satisfied from enquiries petitioner participated.
Kamal Singh case irrelevant; Advisory Board distinguished after personal hearing.
Procedural compliance followed; second representation under consideration.

court_reasoning.text: Preventive detention different from punitive; can rely on facts subject to prosecution; public order wider than security of State.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Criminal instances can justify detention if satisfy need to prevent future disturbance.

court_reasoning.text: Not substituting opinion for detaining authorities unless no reasonable person could be satisfied.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Facts show jeopardy to public order.

court_reasoning.text: Affidavit post-dates initial detention and Advisory Board opinion; cannot vitiate order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court rightly held affidavit does not affect initial order.

court_reasoning.text: Kamal Singh distinguishable as he got personal hearing and persuaded Board.
No evidence of non-application of mind or mala fides; no denial of personal hearing or effective representation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Petitioner must show violation of Art. 21/22.

court_reasoning.text: Under Sec. 14 MISA r/w Sec. 21 General Clauses Act, State can revoke/modify; advisable to refer second representation to Advisory Board.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Implied power to refer subsequent representations analogously.

holdings.text: Preventive detention valid despite criminal prosecution/discharge; grounds sufficient for public order.
Public order elastic concept wider than security of State; criminal acts can justify if threaten public order.
State Government to consider second representation early, possibly referring to Advisory Board under Sec. 14.

precedents_cited.case_name: Golam Hussain alias Gama v. Commissioner of Police, Calcutta & Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Criminal activity can form basis for detention satisfaction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Milan Banik v. State of West Bengal & Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Criminal activity can form basis for detention satisfaction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohd Salim Khan v. Shri C.C. Base & Anr.
precedents_cited.relevance: Criminal activity can form basis for detention satisfaction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sasti Satish Chowdhary v. State of West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Criminal activity can form basis for detention satisfaction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Haradhan Saha v. State of West Bengal & Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Preventive detention qualitative different; not parallel to prosecution; public order wider than State security.

statutes_cited.name: Maintenance of Internal Security Act, 1971
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for detention order, representations, Advisory Board reference, confirmation, revocation/modification.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Habeas corpus petition; protection of personal liberty.

statutes_cited.name: General Clauses Act, 1897
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to revoke/modify orders; read with Sec. 14 MISA.

outcome.summary: Prayer for quashing detention order rejected; detention held prima facie legal. Directed State Government of West Bengal to consider and decide expeditiously the pending second representation in accordance with law, possibly referring to Advisory Board.
outcome.relief_granted: Direction to consider second representation early.

key_quotes.text: "The power of preventive detention is qualitatively different from punitive detention. The power of preventive detention is a precautionary power exercised in reasonable anticipation."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes preventive from punitive detention; clarifies reliance on past acts.

key_quotes.text: "Public Order is necessarily an elastic concept which is, in any case, wider than the security of the State category."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines scope of public order under MISA.

key_quotes.text: "Courts have, no doubt, to zealously guard the personal liberty of the citizen... But, this does not mean that they have to or can rightly and properly assume either the duties cast upon the detaining authorities and Advisory Board."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits judicial role in preventive detention cases.
